awd_titl_txt: NSFGEO-NERC: Equatorial Line Observations (ELO) Field Campaign during the International Years of Maritime Continent Program: Oceanography and Atmospheric Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
The warm shallow seas and mountainous islands of the Maritime Continent (MC, the region between the Indian Ocean and the western Pacific) pose a challenge for atmospheric disturbances propagating through the area.  The larges of these disturbances is the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), a broad envelope of clouds and precipitation that forms in the Indian Ocean and moves slowly eastward as far as the central equatorial Pacific. The MJO affects weather and climate over much of the globe, with US impacts including hurricane formation in the Gulf of Mexico and flooding in California due to atmospheric rivers.  The slow evolution and widespread impacts of the MJO have spurred interest in MJO prediction, and the MC presents a challenge to forecasting as models have difficulty predicting which events will transit the region and which will dissipate within it. The desirability of long-range forecasts of MJO impacts has thus lead to an interest in understanding the mechanisms through which the MC interacts with the MJO and serves as a gatekeeper for their entry into the equatorial Pacific.

This project is one component of the Equatorial Line Observations (ELO) field campaign, which seeks to understand the local MC processes that influence MJO propagation.  The campaign is a joint project between researchers in the US, Great Britain, and Indonesia in which oceanic observations are taken along the equator using sea gliders off the west coast of Sumatra and moorings in the Karimata Strait between Sumatra and Borneo.  The oceanic observations are complemented by land-based observations in eastern Sumatra and on the west coast of Borneo, with deployment scheduled between November 2018 and February 2019.  ELO is part of a larger international effort known as the Years of the Maritime Continent, organized under the auspices of the World Meteorological Organization.

The campaign targets three factors which are hypothesized to influence MJO propagation through the MC.  The first is interactions between atmospheric disturbances and the underlying ocean.  Abundant rainfall over the internal seas of the MC produces a shallow surface layer of fresh water which can be warmed and cooled rapidly by variations in sunlight reaching the surface, wind-driven evaporation, and other factors.  Variations in sea surface temperature can in turn influence cloudiness and precipitation, and the campaign seeks to understand how this air-sea coupling affects eastward propagating atmospheric disturbance.

The second is the interaction of the MJO with convectively coupled Kelvin waves (CCKWs), which are smaller equatorial weather disturbances which propagate eastward at a faster rate than the MJO and are regarded as its "building blocks".  The PIs hypothesize that the problems with the representation of MJO propagation through the MC seen in forecast models are related to poor simulation of CCKW activity in the region.

The third is the interaction of CCKWs with the diurnal cycle of precipitation in the MC, as intense precipitation generally occurs after noon over Sumatra and Borneo but in the morning over the Karimata Strait separating them.  The distance between the islands is such that a CCKW passing over Sumatra during the rainy part of the day is likely to arrive at Borneo in time for the precipitation maximum on the following day.  The PI hypothesizes that the extra condensational heating received by CCKWs which are synchronized with the island diurnal cycles could favor their growth and further interaction with the MJO.

The work has societal as well as scientific value given the worldwide impacts of the MJO and the potential for improvement of MJO-related forecasts. The work also promotes international capacity building in atmospheric science and operational forecasting, as it is conducted in collaboration with Indonesian partners. The campaign involves PhD students from the US, Great Britain, and Indonesia, thus providing future workforce development in this research area.

por.por_cntn:
To improve understanding of the atmospheric conditions that lead to floods in Sumatra, a study was conducted with a focus on convectively coupled Kelvin waves as a key contributor. A 5-year flood record for Sumatra was analyzed, using data from governmental reports and crowd-sourced sources. It was found that convectively coupled Kelvin waves played a critical role in the majority of analyzed floods, with enhanced precipitation related to these waves present in over 90% of flood events and responsible for precipitation anomalies in 30% of these events. These findings have the potential to inform the development of more effective flood prevention and response strategies, which could save lives and reduce the financial costs associated with floods. The broader impacts of this research are significant, as floods are a major contributor to natural disasters. The use of crowd-sourced data in this study also highlights the potential for engaging communities in scientific research, which can enhance the quality and scope of research and build capacity and interest in science among the general public. This study was published in the journal Nature Communication in 2019.

In order to identify and analyze the factors contributing to fires in Riau, Sumatra over the 2014-2019 timeframe, a study was conducted using tweets related to fires in the region. The TAGGS algorithm was applied to geoparse the tweets based on user information and references to specific locations, and online newspapers covering Riau in 2019 were also analyzed to gather additional information about the causes and impacts of fires. A correlation analysis was conducted between meteorological data, Twitter activity, and satellite-derived hotspots, and existing approaches for detecting fire activity used by the Indonesian government and other agencies were reviewed. Based on the findings, a novel approach for early fire detection using crowdsourced data from tweets was proposed. The broader impacts of this research are significant because fires can have significant negative impacts on communities, including health effects, animal mortality, ecosystem disruption, visibility, and air quality. By using crowdsourced data to identify and analyze fires, the potential exists to develop effective fire prevention and response strategies by engaging local authorities. This research was published in the journal Sustainability in 2021.

 

Another research, accepted for publication in Nature Communications in 2023, investigates the atmospheric conditions that led to the unusual development and consequences of Tropical Cyclone Seroja, which impacted Indonesian land and East Timor in April 2021, bringing historic flooding and impacting Western Australia. It was found that the cyclone's genesis was associated with enhanced equatorial convection and warm sea surface anomalies, which occurred on the leading edge of a Madden-Julian Oscillation event. Within the Madden-Julian Oscillation, the interaction between a convectively coupled equatorial Rossby wave and two convectively coupled Kelvin waves created "perfect storm" conditions and led to cyclogenesis. The study suggests that looking at tropical waves in warmer climates may provide insight into the potential for such strong storms to become more common due to climate change. The intellectual merit of this research lies in the analysis of the atmospheric conditions that led to the unusual development and consequences of TC Seroja, and the exploration of the potential link to climate change. The broader impacts of the research are significant because understanding the factors that contribute to the frequency and intensity of tropical cyclones has the potential to develop more effective prevention and response strategies.

 

In the study published in the journal "Monthly Weather Review" in 2021, the role of equatorial waves in the development of extreme rain and flood events in southwest Sulawesi, Indonesia was investigated. It was found that a convectively coupled Kelvin wave (CCKW) and a convectively coupled equatorial Rossby wave (CCERW) were key contributors to a heavy rainfall and flood event in the region on January 22, 2019. It was also found that the probability of extreme rain and flood events occurring during the combined activity of CCKWs and CCERWs was 8 times greater than on a random day. The intellectual merit of this research lies in the identification of the role of CCKWs and CCERWs in extreme weather events.
